title: UAE's Edutech startup LearnHub secures $7.5 million to expand its AI-powered learning platform
content: LearnHub, a UAE-based edutech startup that offers an AI-powered learning platform, has raised $7.5 million in a Series A funding round led by Global Ventures with participation from BECO Capital and Wamda Capital.

Founded in 2022 by Sarah Al-Nasser and Ravi Sharma, LearnHub uses artificial intelligence to personalize learning experiences for students in K-12 and higher education. The platform adapts to each student's learning style, pace, and preferences, offering customized content and assessments.

"Education is not one-size-fits-all, and our platform recognizes that each student has unique needs," said Sarah Al-Nasser, co-founder and CEO of LearnHub. "This funding will help us enhance our AI capabilities and expand our reach across the MENA region."

The startup claims its platform has shown impressive results, with students showing a 40% improvement in subject mastery compared to traditional learning methods. Currently, LearnHub serves over 50,000 students across the UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Egypt.

The fresh capital will be used to further develop LearnHub's AI algorithms, expand the content library to cover more subjects and curricula, and accelerate growth in new markets including Jordan, Kuwait, and Qatar.

"We're particularly excited about the potential of our new 'Study Buddy' AI feature, which acts as a personalized tutor available 24/7 to answer questions and provide guidance," explained Ravi Sharma, co-founder and CTO. "Early testing shows that students who use this feature regularly see a 25% higher engagement rate."

LearnHub operates on a subscription model, with schools and universities paying an annual fee based on the number of students. The platform also offers a direct-to-consumer option for individual students or parents.

"EdTech in MENA is at an inflection point, with increasing adoption of digital learning tools accelerated by the pandemic," said Noor Sweid, Managing Partner at Global Ventures. "LearnHub's approach to personalized learning through AI is exactly what the market needs, and we're thrilled to support their vision."

According to a recent report by Ken Research, the MENA EdTech market is expected to reach $7 billion by 2026, growing at a CAGR of 15% from 2021. LearnHub is positioning itself to capture a significant portion of this expanding market.

The startup has also announced plans to launch a teacher training program to help educators make the most of AI tools in their classrooms, addressing a critical gap in professional development in the region.

title: Morocco's Agritech startup FarmTech raises $4.2 million to modernize small-scale farming
content: FarmTech, a Morocco-based agritech startup that helps small-scale farmers improve productivity through technology, has raised $4.2 million in a seed funding round led by Algebra Ventures, with participation from Outliers Venture Capital and several angel investors.

Founded in 2023 by Mohammed El-Fassi and Clara Dubois, FarmTech offers a suite of tools including a mobile app that provides weather forecasts, crop disease detection using smartphone cameras, marketplace access for selling produce, and micro-financing options.

"Small-scale farmers in North Africa face numerous challenges, from limited access to information and markets to the growing impacts of climate change," said Mohammed El-Fassi, co-founder and CEO of FarmTech. "Our platform addresses these challenges by putting technology directly in farmers' hands."
The startup currently serves over 15,000 farmers across Morocco, helping them increase crop yields by an average of 30% while reducing water usage by 20% through smart irrigation recommendations.
With the new funding, FarmTech plans to expand its operations to Tunisia and Algeria, enhance its AI-powered disease detection capabilities, and develop new features for livestock management.

"What sets FarmTech apart is their deep understanding of local farming challenges and their ability to create simple, accessible solutions that don't require expensive equipment or technical expertise," said Karim Hussein, Managing Partner at Algebra Ventures.

The company's business model includes a freemium approach, where basic features are available for free, while advanced features require a subscription. FarmTech also generates revenue through commissions on marketplace transactions and partnerships with agricultural input suppliers.

"We're particularly proud of our impact on female farmers, who make up 40% of our user base," added Clara Dubois, co-founder and COO. "Many of these women have become digital ambassadors in their communities, training others to use technology to improve their farming practices."

Agriculture remains a critical sector in North Africa, employing approximately 40% of the workforce in Morocco alone. However, the sector faces challenges of low productivity, limited access to modern farming techniques, and vulnerability to climate change.

FarmTech aims to address these challenges by democratizing access to agricultural technology and knowledge, potentially transforming the livelihoods of millions of small-scale farmers across the region.
